title: 111_s1931
content: The Act may be cited as the "Strengthening the Oversight of Nuclear Nonproliferation Act of 2009". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "Strengthening the Oversight of Nuclear Nonproliferation Act of 2009," defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees" and "Commission." The former includes specific Senate and House committees, while the latter refers to the Commission on the Prevention of Weapons of Mass Destruction. The Commission on the Prevention of Weapons of Mass Destruction Proliferation and Terrorism was established by the Implementing Recommendation of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007. It includes a Coordinator and Deputy Coordinator for the Prevention of Weapons of Mass Destruction Proliferation and Terrorism. The 9/11 Commission Act of 2007 defines terms like highly enriched uranium, IAEA, and special nuclear material. The 9/11 Commission Act of 2007 defines terms related to nuclear nonproliferation efforts. The Coordinator must submit an annual report to congressional committees on findings and recommendations of the Commission regarding financial incentives for promoting civilian nuclear energy abroad and actions taken to improve secure civilian storage of highly enriched uranium. The annual report must include details on the United States Government's spending on fuel for civilian reactors using highly enriched uranium, actions taken to implement the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Act, and steps to enhance physical security at nuclear facilities storing special nuclear material. The United States Government assesses the capabilities of the IAEA in detecting possible military diversions and recommends updates to its definitions of special nuclear material. The United States Government recommends updating definitions of special nuclear material for detecting military diversions and nuclear bomb creation timelines. If the Coordinator or Deputy Coordinator are not appointed, the President must submit the required report. SEC. 4. REPORT ON UNITED STATES WORK WITH IAEA ON NUCLEAR NONPROLIFERATION. The Coordinator must submit a report to congressional committees within a year of this Act's enactment, detailing the findings and recommendations of the Commission. The report will cover the progress of the US Government's collaboration with the IAEA Director General on establishing a safeguards user fee and assessing the IAEA's ability to meet inspection goals. The report required under this section aims to address situations where achieving IAEA inspection goals is not possible. It suggests promoting transparency at suspect sites, implementing real-time surveillance equipment, and reporting transfers of items on nuclear suppliers' lists to the IAEA in advance. The President must submit the report if the Coordinator or Deputy Coordinator have not been appointed as required by the Implementing Recommendation of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out reporting requirements for fiscal year 2010 and beyond.
